importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on this date, marking a current development in the context of climate vulnerability and Indigenous knowledge in Pakistan.
The GLOF-II project was launched in 2017, highlighting a long-standing government initiative to combat glacial lake outburst floods using technology.
Pakistan experienced nearly 90 glacial floods between 2019 and 2022, indicating a period of increasing climate-related disasters.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2019 to 2022 saw a significant number of glacial floods in Pakistan, demonstrating a climate emergency in high-altitude regions.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, such as observing natural signs like sudden rainfall, animal behavior, and unusual sounds, is being used by local communities in northern Pakistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).
Despite government investments in early warning systems (EWS), including the $37 million GLOF-II project, communities lack trust due to system failures, lack of maintenance, and poor communication.
Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan prefer traditional human-based warning methods—such as gunfire signals or fire alarms—because they are more reliable and culturally embedded.
A shepherd named Wasiyat Khan and others successfully saved lives during a GLOF event using these Indigenous methods, demonstrating their practical effectiveness.
Pakistan, despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, is among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations due to rising temperatures and glacial melt.
The government has awarded monetary rewards to individuals like Wasiyat Khan for saving lives, recognizing the value of community-based resilience.
There is growing criticism of official EWS implementation, with reports stating systems are non-operational or unresponsive, and with no investigations into failures conducted.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who used Indigenous knowledge to save villagers during a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) event.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wasiyat Khan exemplifies how Indigenous knowledge can be critical in emergency response when technological systems fail.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Skardu Valley in Gilgit-Baltistan who recalled using traditional signals to warn villagers of a flash flood.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides a detailed account of how traditional human-based warning methods, passed down through generations, are still effective and trusted.

namedEntities.name: Zaki Abbas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Islamabad-based journalist who writes on climate change and critiques the failure of EWS implementation in Gilgit-Baltistan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He highlights the lack of community trust in EWS and the political and institutional failures in implementation.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan Meteorological Department
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The government body responsible for monitoring weather and disseminating data through early warning systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the functioning of EWS, although its systems are criticized for being ineffective and disconnected from local communities.

namedEntities.name: National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The official body that assesses climate risks and warns of glacial lake outburst floods in Pakistan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has issued projections on reduced snowfall and increased glacier melt, emphasizing climate vulnerability in northern Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: GLOF (Glacial Lake Outburst Flood)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A climate-related disaster caused by the sudden release of water from glacial lakes, common in Pakistan’s mountainous regions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary climate threat being addressed by both Indigenous knowledge and government early warning systems.

namedEntities.name: GLOF-II Project
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A $37 million government initiative launched in 2017 to improve early warning systems for GLOFs using sensors, sirens, and training.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It illustrates the failure of technological investments when community trust and operational functionality are lacking.

namedEntities.name: Gilgit-Baltistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in northern Pakistan known for its high altitude, glaciers, and vulnerability to GLOFs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary region affected by glacial melt and where Indigenous knowledge and EWS are both in use and contested.

namedEntities.name: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A province in Pakistan where early warning systems are also being implemented in climate-vulnerable areas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is mentioned as another region where EWS systems are present but face community skepticism and operational issues.

namedEntities.name: World Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global institution that has assessed Pakistan’s climate vulnerability and temperature rise since the 1950s.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides data showing that Pakistan has experienced a 1.3°C temperature rise since the 1950s, twice the global average, highlighting climate sensitivity.

namedEntities.name: UNDP (United Nations Development Programme)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international body that identifies challenges in global early warning systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It notes that global EWS face issues like weak institutional capacity and communication barriers, which are mirrored in Pakistan’s context.

namedEntities.name: Musadiq Malik
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s climate change minister who emphasized the deadly impact of glacial floods and the need for better climate resilience.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He articulates the severity of the climate crisis and the human cost of GLOFs in Pakistan.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing changes in weather, animal behavior, and using traditional signals like gunfire—is being used by shepherds to predict and warn of glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially in the absence of reliable and trusted early warning systems. Despite government investments in technological systems like the $37 million GLOF-II project, communities report frequent failures, lack of maintenance, and poor communication, leading to a deep erosion of trust. In contrast, stories from individuals like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain show how traditional human-based responses have successfully saved lives. This highlights a critical issue: technology alone cannot ensure safety without community engagement, cultural relevance, and operational integrity. As climate change intensifies, with rising temperatures and glacial melt, the resilience of local knowledge systems is proving vital to protecting lives and livelihoods in Pakistan’s most vulnerable areas.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
